Digital Signal Processing - Signals-Definition
==============================================

Definition
----------

Anything that carries information can be called as signal. It can also be defined as a physical quantity that varies with time, temperature, pressure or with any independent variables such as speech signal or video signal.

**Note** − Any unwanted signal interfering with the main signal is termed as noise. So, noise is also a signal but unwanted.

According to their representation and processing, signals can be classified into various categories details of which are discussed below.

Continuous Time Signals
-----------------------

Continuous-time signals are defined along a continuum of time and are thus, represented by a continuous independent variable. Continuous-time signals are often referred to as analog signals.

This type of signal shows continuity both in amplitude and time. These will have values at each instant of time. Sine and cosine functions are the best example of Continuous time signal.

![Continuous Time Signals](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/continuous_time_signals.jpg)

The signal shown above is an example of continuous time signal because we can get value of signal at each instant of time.

Discrete Time signals
---------------------

The signals, which are defined at discrete times are known as discrete signals. Therefore, every independent variable has distinct value. Thus, they are represented as sequence of numbers.

Although speech and video signals have the privilege to be represented in both continuous and discrete time format; under certain circumstances, they are identical. Amplitudes also show discrete characteristics. Perfect example of this is a digital signal; whose amplitude and time both are discrete.

![Discrete Time signals](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/discrete_time_signals.jpg)

The figure above depicts a discrete signal’s discrete amplitude characteristic over a period of time. Mathematically, these types of signals can be formularized as;

Digital Signal Processing - Basic CT Signals
============================================

To test a system, generally, standard or basic signals are used. These signals are the basic building blocks for many complex signals. Hence, they play a very important role in the study of signals and systems.

Sinusoidal Signal
-----------------

A signal, which is continuous in nature is known as continuous signal. General format of a sinusoidal signal is

$$\\Delta(\\frac{t}{\\tau}) = \\begin{cases}1-(\\frac{2|t|}{\\tau}) & for|t|&lt;\\frac{\\tau}{2}\\\\0 & for|t|&gt;\\frac{\\tau}{2}\\end{cases}$$
![Triangular Pulse Signal](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/triangular_pulse_signal.jpg)

This signal is symmetrical about Y-axis. Hence, it is also termed as even signal.

Digital Signal Processing - Basic DT Signals
============================================

We have seen that how the basic signals can be represented in Continuous time domain. Let us see how the basic signals can be represented in Discrete Time Domain.

The figure given above shows the graphical representation of a parabolic sequence.

Sinusoidal Signal
-----------------

All continuous-time signals are periodic. The discrete-time sinusoidal sequences may or may not be periodic. They depend on the value of ω. For a discrete time signal to be periodic, the angular frequency ω must be a rational multiple of 2π.

![Sinusoidal Signal](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/sinusoidal_signal.jpg)

A discrete sinusoidal signal is shown in the figure above.

Discrete form of a sinusoidal signal can be represented in the format −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-927" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-928" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-929" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-930" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-931" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-932" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-933" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">A</span><span id="MJXp-Span-934" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-935" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-936" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-937" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-938" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-939" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-940" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ϕ</span><span id="MJXp-Span-941" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-42-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1016" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1017" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1018" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1019" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1020" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1021" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1022" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1023" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1024" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.159em;">sin</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1025" class="mo"></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1026" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1027" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">ω</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1028" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1029" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.211em;">+</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1030" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.211em;">ϕ</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1031" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

$$N =\\frac{2\\pi m}{\\omega}$$

Where, N and m are integers.

DSP - Classification of CT Signals
==================================

Continuous time signals can be classified according to different conditions or operations performed on the signals.

Even and Odd Signals
--------------------

### Even Signal

A signal is said to be even if it satisfies the following condition;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-950" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-951" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-952" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-953" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-954" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-955" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-956" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-957" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-958" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-959" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-960" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-44-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1042" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1043" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1044" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1045" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1046" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1047" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1048" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1049" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1050" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1051" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1052" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1053" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

*x*( − *t*) = *x*(*t*)

Time reversal of the signal does not imply any change on amplitude here. For example, consider the triangular wave shown below.

![CT Even Signal1](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/ct_even_signal1.jpg)

The triangular signal is an even signal. Since, it is symmetrical about Y-axis. We can say it is mirror image about Y-axis.

Consider another signal as shown in the figure below.

![CT Even Signal2](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/ct_even_signal2.jpg)

We can see that the above signal is even as it is symmetrical about Y-axis.

### Odd Signal

A signal is said to be odd, if it satisfies the following condition

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-961" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-962" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-963" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-964" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-965" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-966" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-967" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-968" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-969" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-970" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-971" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-972" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-45-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1054" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1055" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1056" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1057" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1058" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1059" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1060" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1061" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1062" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1063" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1064" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1065" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1066" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

*x*( − *t*) =  − *x*(*t*)

Here, both the time reversal and amplitude change takes place simultaneously.

![CT Odd Signal](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/ct_odd_signal.jpg)

In the figure above, we can see a step signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-973" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-974" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-46-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1067" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1068" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1069" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*. To test whether it is an odd signal or not, first we do the time reversal i.e. x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-975" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-976" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-977" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-47-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1070" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1071" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1072" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1073" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span> − *t* and the result is as shown in the figure. Then we reverse the amplitude of the resultant signal i.e. –x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-978" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-979" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-980" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-48-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1074" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1075" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1076" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1077" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span> − *t* and we get the result as shown in figure.

If we compare the first and the third waveform, we can see that they are same, i.e. x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-981" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-982" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-49-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1078" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1079" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1080" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*= -x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-983" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-984" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-985" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-50-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1081" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1082" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1083" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1084" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span> − *t*, which satisfies our criteria. Therefore, the above signal is an Odd signal.

Some important results related to even and odd signals are given below.

-   Even × Even = Even
-   Odd × Odd = Even
-   Even × Odd = Odd
-   Even ± Even = Even
-   Odd ± Odd = Odd
-   Even ± Odd = Neither even nor odd

### Representation of any signal into even or odd form

Some signals cannot be directly classified into even or odd type. These are represented as a combination of both even and odd signal.

Periodic and Non-Periodic Signals
---------------------------------

### Periodic Signals

Periodic signal repeats itself after certain interval of time. We can show this in equation form as −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1221" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-1222" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1223" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1224" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1225" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1226" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1227" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1228" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1229" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1230" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1231" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">±</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1232" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1233" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span></span></span>

Fundamental time period <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1246" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-1247" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">F</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1248" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1249" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">P</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-68-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1388" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1389" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1390" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">F<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.107em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1391" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">T<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.107em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1392" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">P<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.107em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>*F**T**P* is the smallest positive and fixed value of time for which signal is periodic.

![Periodic Signals](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/periodic_signals.jpg)

A triangular signal is shown in the figure above of amplitude A. Here, the signal is repeating after every 1 sec. Therefore, we can say that the signal is periodic and its FTP is 1 sec.

### Non-Periodic Signal

Simply, we can say, the signals, which are not periodic are non-periodic in nature. As obvious, these signals will not repeat themselves after any interval time.

Non-periodic signals do not follow a certain format; therefore, no particular mathematical equation can describe them.

Energy and Power Signals
------------------------

A signal is said to be an Energy signal, if and only if, the total energy contained is finite and nonzero <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1250" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-1251" class="MJXp-mn">0</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1252" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1253" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">E</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1254" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1255" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-1256" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">∞</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-69-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1393" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1394" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1395" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">0</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1396" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">&lt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1397" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">E<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.003em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1398" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">&lt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1399" class="texatom" style="padding-left: 0.263em;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1400" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1401" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">∞</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>0 &lt; *E* &lt; ∞. Therefore, for any energy type signal, the total normalized signal is finite and non-zero.

A sinusoidal AC current signal is a perfect example of Energy type signal because it is in positive half cycle in one case and then is negative in the next half cycle. Therefore, its average power becomes zero.

A lossless capacitor is also a perfect example of Energy type signal because when it is connected to a source it charges up to its optimum level and when the source is removed, it dissipates that equal amount of energy through a load and makes its average power to zero.

![Energy Signals](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/energy_signals.jpg)

For any finite signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1257" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-1258" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-70-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1402" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1403" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1404" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t* the energy can be symbolized as E and is written as;

### Power type Signals

A signal is said to be power type signal, if and only if, normalized average power is finite and non-zero i.e. <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1279" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-1280" class="MJXp-mn">0</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1281" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1282" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1283" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1284" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-1285" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">∞</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-72-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-1429" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1430" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1431" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">0</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1432" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">&lt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1433" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">p</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1434" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">&lt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1435" class="texatom" style="padding-left: 0.263em;"><span id="MathJax-Span-1436" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1437" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">∞</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>0 &lt; *p* &lt; ∞. DSP - Classification of DT Signals
==================================

Just like Continuous time signals, Discrete time signals can be classified according to the conditions or operations on the signals.

Even and Odd Signals
--------------------

### Even Signal

A signal is said to be even or symmetric if it satisfies the following condition;

Periodic and Non-Periodic Signals
---------------------------------

A discrete time signal is periodic if and only if, it satisfies the following condition −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1653" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-1654" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1655" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1656" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1657" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1658" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1659" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1660" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1661" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1662" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1663" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1664" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

Frequencies of discrete sinusoidal signals are separated by integral multiple of <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-1844" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-1845" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-1846" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">π</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-118-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-2077" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-2078" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-2079" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">2</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2080" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">π<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.003em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>2*π*.

Energy and Power Signals
------------------------

$$P = \\lim\_{N \\to \\infty} \\frac{1}{2N+1}\\displaystyle\\sum\\limits\_{n=-N}^{+N} |x(n)|^2$$

Here, power is finite i.e. 0&lt;P&lt;∞. However, there are some signals, which belong to neither energy nor power type signal.

DSP - Miscellaneous Signals
===========================

There are other signals, which are a result of operation performed on them. Some common type of signals are discussed below.

Now, again compare, both the equations just as we did for conjugate signals. Here, we will find that the real part is odd and the imaginary part is even. This is the condition for a signal to become conjugate anti-symmetric type.

Orthogonal Signal
-----------------

The signals, which contain odd harmonics (3<sup>rd</sup>, 5<sup>th</sup>, 7<sup>th</sup> ...etc.) and have different frequencies, are mutually orthogonal to each other.

In trigonometric type signals, sine functions and cosine functions are also orthogonal to each other; provided, they have same frequency and are in same phase. Accordingly, we can classify the shifting into two categories named as Time shifting and Amplitude shifting, these are subsequently discussed below.

Time Shifting
-------------

Time shifting means, shifting of signals in the time domain. Mathematically, it can be written as

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2412" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-2413" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2414" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2415" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2416" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2417" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">→</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2418" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2419" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2420" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2421" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2422" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2423" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-163-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-2708" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-2709" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-2710" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2711" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2712" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2713" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2714" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">→</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2715" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">y<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.003em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-2716" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2717" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2718" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.211em;">+</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2719" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.211em;">k</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2720" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

*x*(*t*) → *y*(*t* + *k*)

This K value may be positive or it may be negative. According to the sign of k value, we have two types of shifting named as Right shifting and Left shifting.

### Case 1 <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2424" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2425" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2426" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&gt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2427" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-164-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-2721" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 119%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-2722" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-2723" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">K<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.049em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-2724" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">&gt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2725" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span>*K* &gt; 0

When K is greater than zero, the shifting of the signal takes place towards "left" in the time domain. Therefore, this type of shifting is known as Left Shifting of the signal.

**Example**

![Time Shifting Case1 Example](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_shifting_case1_example.jpg)

### Case 2 <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2428" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2429" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2430" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2431" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-165-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-2726" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 119%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-2727" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-2728" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">K<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.049em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-2729" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">&lt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2730" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span>*K* &lt; 0

When K is less than zero the shifting of signal takes place towards right in the time domain. Therefore, this type of shifting is known as Right shifting.

**Example**

The figure given below shows right shifting of a signal by 2.

![Time Shifting Case2 Example](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_shifting_case2_example.jpg)

This K value may be positive or negative. Accordingly, we have two types of amplitude shifting which are subsequently discussed below.

### Case 1 <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2457" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2458" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2459" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&gt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2460" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-168-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-2758" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 119%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-2759" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-2760" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">K<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.049em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-2761" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">&gt;</span><span id="MathJax-Span-2762" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.282em;">0</span></span></span></span></span></span>*K* &gt; 0

DSP - Operations on Signals Scaling
===================================

Scaling of a signal means, a constant is multiplied with the time or amplitude of the signal.

Time Scaling
------------

If a constant is multiplied to the time axis then it is known as Time scaling. This can be mathematically represented as;

Therefore, scaling can also be divided into two categories as discussed below.

### Time Compression

Whenever alpha is greater than zero, the signal’s amplitude gets divided by alpha whereas the value of the Y-axis remains the same. This is known as Time Compression.

**Example**

Let us consider a signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2689" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2690" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-183-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3017" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3018" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3019" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*, which is shown as in figure below. Let us take the value of alpha as 2. So, y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2691" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2692" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-184-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3020" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3021" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3022" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t* will be x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2693" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2694" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2695" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-185-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3023" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3024" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3025" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">2</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3026" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>2*t*, which is illustrated in the given figure.

![Time Compression Example](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_compression_example.jpg)

Clearly, we can see from the above figures that the time magnitude in y-axis remains the same but the amplitude in x-axis reduces from 4 to 2. Therefore, it is a case of Time Compression.

### Time Expansion

When the time is divided by the constant alpha, the Y-axis magnitude of the signal get multiplied alpha times, keeping X-axis magnitude as it is. Therefore, this is called Time expansion type signal.

**Example**

Let us consider a square signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2696" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2697" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-186-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3027" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3028" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3029" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*, of magnitude 1. When we time scaled it by a constant 3, such that <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2698" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2699" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2700" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; Amplitude Scaling
-----------------

Multiplication of a constant with the amplitude of the signal causes amplitude scaling. Depending upon the sign of the constant, it may be either amplitude scaling or attenuation. Let us consider a square wave signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2715" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2716" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-188-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3048" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3049" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3050" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t* = Π<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2717" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2718" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2719" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-2720" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-2721" class="MJXp-mn">4</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-189-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3051" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3052" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3053" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3054" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-3055" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3056" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">/</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-3057" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">4</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*/4.

Suppose we define another function y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2722" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2723" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-190-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3058" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3059" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3060" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t* = 2 Π<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2724" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2725" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2726" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-2727" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-2728" class="MJXp-mn">4</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-191-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3061" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3062" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3063" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3064" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-3065" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3066" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">/</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-3067" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">4</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t*/4. In this case, value of y-axis will be doubled, keeping the time axis value as it is. The is illustrated in the figure given below.

DSP - Operations on Signals Reversal
====================================

Whenever the time in a signal gets multiplied by -1, the signal gets reversed. It produces its mirror image about Y or X-axis. This is known as Reversal of the signal.

Reversal can be classified into two types based on the condition whether the time or the amplitude of the signal is multiplied by -1.

Time Reversal
-------------

Whenever signal’s time is multiplied by -1, it is known as time reversal of the signal. In this case, the signal produces its mirror image about Y-axis. Mathematically, this can be written as;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2742" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-2743" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2744" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2745" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2746" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2747" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">→</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2748" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2749" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2750" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2751" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2752" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">→</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2753" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2754" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2755" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2756" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2757" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-197-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3087" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3088" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3089" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3090" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3091" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3092" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3093" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">→</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3094" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">y<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.003em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-3095" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3096" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3097" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3098" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">→</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3099" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3100" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3101" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3102" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3103" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

*x*(*t*) → *y*(*t*) → *x*( − *t*)

This can be best understood by the following example.

![Time Reversal](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_reversal.jpg)

In the above example, we can clearly see that the signal has been reversed about its Y-axis. So, it is one kind of time scaling also, but here the scaling quantity is <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2758" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2759" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2760" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-198-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3104" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3105" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3106" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3107" class="mn" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">1</span></span></span></span></span></span> − 1 always.

Amplitude Reversal
------------------

Whenever the amplitude of a signal is multiplied by -1, then it is known as amplitude reversal. In this case, the signal produces its mirror image about X-axis. Mathematically, this can be written as;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2761" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-2762" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2763" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2764" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2765" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2766" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">→</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2767" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2768" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2769" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2770" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2771" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">→</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2772" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2773" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2774" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2775" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-2776" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-199-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3108" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3109" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3110" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3111" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3112" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3113" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3114" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">→</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3115" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic; padding-left: 0.263em;">y<span style="display: inline-block; overflow: hidden; height: 1px; width: 0.003em;"></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-3116" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3117" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3118" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3119" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">→</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3120" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main; padding-left: 0.263em;">−</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3121" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3122" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3123" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span><span id="MathJax-Span-3124" class="mo" style="font-family: MathJax_Main;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>

*x*(*t*) → *y*(*t*) →  − *x*(*t*)

Consider the following example. Amplitude reversal can be seen clearly.

![Amplitude Reversal](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/amplitude_reversal.jpg)

DSP - Operations on Signals Differentiation
===========================================

Two very important operations performed on the signals are Differentiation and Integration.

Differentiation
---------------

Differentiation of any signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-2777" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-2778" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-200-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processed" tabindex="0" style=""><span id="MathJax-Span-3125" class="math"><span style="display: inline-block; position: relative; width: 0em; height: 0px; font-size: 120%;"><span style="position: absolute;"><span id="MathJax-Span-3126" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-3127" class="mi" style="font-family: MathJax_Math-italic;">t</span></span></span></span></span></span>*t* means slope representation of that signal with respect to time. $$x(t)\\rightarrow \\frac{dx(t)}{dt}$$

In the case of OPAMP differentiation, this methodology is very helpful. We can easily differentiate a signal graphically rather than using the formula. However, the condition is that the signal must be either rectangular or triangular type, which happens in most cases.

<table><thead><tr class="header"><th>Original Signal</th><th>Differentiated Signal</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td>Ramp</td><td>Step</td></tr><tr class="even"><td>Step</td><td>Impulse</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>Impulse</td><td>1</td></tr></tbody></table>

The above table illustrates the condition of the signal after being differentiated. For example, a ramp signal converts into a step signal after differentiation. Similarly, a unit step signal becomes an impulse signal.

To start with, we will start differentiating the given equation. We know that the ramp signal after differentiation gives unit step signal.

DSP - Operations on Signals Integration
=======================================

Steps for convolution
---------------------

Digital Signal Processing - Static Systems
==========================================

Some systems have feedback and some do not. Those, which do not have feedback systems, their output depends only upon the present values of the input. Past value of the data is not present at that time. These types of systems are known as static systems. It does not depend upon future values too.

Since these systems do not have any past record, so they do not have any memory also. Therefore, we say all static systems are memory-less systems. Let us take an example to understand this concept much better.

Example
-------

Let us verify whether the following systems are static systems or not.

-   <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4079" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4080" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4081" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4082" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4083" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4084" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4085" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4086" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4087" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4088" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4089" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4090" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4091" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4092" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4093" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4094" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4095" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-270-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + *x*(*t* − 1)
