-   <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4107" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4108" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4109" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4110" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4111" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4112" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4113" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4114" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4115" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4116" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4117" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4118" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4119" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4120" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4121" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4122" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-272-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x* = sin \[*x*(*t*)\]

### a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4123" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4124" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4125" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4126" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4127" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4128" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4129" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4130" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4131" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4132" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4133" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4134" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4135" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4136" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4137" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4138" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4139" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-273-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + *x*(*t* − 1)

Here, x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4140" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4141" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-274-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* is the present value. It has no relation with the past values of the time. So, it is a static system. However, in case of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4142" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4143" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4144" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4145" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-275-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* − 1, if we put t = 0, it will reduce to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4146" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4147" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4148" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-276-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span> − 1 which is a past value dependent. So, it is not static. Therefore here y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4149" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4150" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-277-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* is not a static system.

### b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4151" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4152" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4153" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4154" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4155" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4156" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4157" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4158" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4159" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4160" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4161" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-278-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x*(2*t*)

If we substitute t = 2, the result will be y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4162" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4163" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-279-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* = x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4164" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4165" class="MJXp-mn">4</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-280-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>4. Again, it is future value dependent. So, it is also not a static system.

### c) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4166" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4167" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4168" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4169" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4170" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4171" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4172" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4173" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4174" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4175" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4176" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4177" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4178" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4179" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4180" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4181" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-281-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x* = sin \[*x*(*t*)\]

In this expression, we are dealing with sine function. The range of sine function lies within -1 to +1. So, whatever the values we substitute for x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4182" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4183" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-282-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t*, we will get in between -1 to +1. Therefore, we can say it is not dependent upon any past or future values. Hence, it is a static system.

From the above examples, we can draw the following conclusions −

-   Any system having time shifting is not static.
-   Any system having amplitude shifting is also not static.
-   Integration and differentiation cases are also not static.

Digital Signal Processing - Dynamic Systems
===========================================

If a system depends upon the past and future value of the signal at any instant of the time then it is known as dynamic system. Unlike static systems, these are not memory less systems. They store past and future values. Therefore, they require some memory. Let us understand this theory better through some examples.

Examples
--------

Find out whether the following systems are dynamic.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4184" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4185" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4186" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4187" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4188" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4189" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4190" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4191" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4192" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4193" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4194" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4195" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-283-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* + 1)

In this case if we put t = 1 in the equation, it will be converted to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4196" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4197" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-284-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>2, which is a future dependent value. Because here we are giving input as 1 but it is showing value for x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4198" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4199" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-285-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>2. As it is a future dependent signal, so clearly it is a dynamic system.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4200" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4201" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4202" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4203" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4204" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4205" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4206" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">R</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4207" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4208" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">a</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4209" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">l</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4210" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4211" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4212" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4213" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4214" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4215" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-286-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *R**e**a**l*\[*x*(*t*)\]

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4216" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-4217" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4218" class="MJXp-mfrac" style="vertical-align: 0.25em;"><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-4219" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4220" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4221" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4222" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4223" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4224" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4225" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4226" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4227" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4228" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-4229" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4230" class="MJXp-mo MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;">∗</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4231" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span><span class="MJXp-box" style="margin-top: -0.9em;"><span class="MJXp-denom"><span class="MJXp-rule" style="height: 1em; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1px solid; margin: 0.1em 0px;"></span><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-4232" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-287-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

$$= \\frac{\[x(t)+x(t)^\*\]}{2}$$

In this case, whatever the value we will put it will show that time real value signal. It has no dependency on future or past values. Therefore, it is not a dynamic system rather it is a static system.

**c) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4233" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4234" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4235" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4236" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4237" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4238" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4239" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">E</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4240" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">v</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4241" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4242" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4243" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4244" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4245" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4246" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4247" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4248" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-288-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *E**v**e**n*\[*x*(*t*)\]

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4249" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-4250" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4251" class="MJXp-mfrac" style="vertical-align: 0.25em;"><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-4252" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4253" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4254" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4255" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4256" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4257" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4258" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4259" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4260" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4261" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4262" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4263" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span><span class="MJXp-box" style="margin-top: -0.9em;"><span class="MJXp-denom"><span class="MJXp-rule" style="height: 1em; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1px solid; margin: 0.1em 0px;"></span><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-4264" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-289-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

$$= \\frac{\[x(t)+x(-t)\]}{2}$$

Here, if we will substitute t = 1, one signal shows x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4265" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4266" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-290-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>1 and another will show x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4267" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4268" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4269" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-291-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span> − 1 which is a past value. Similarly, if we will put t = -1 then one signal will show x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4270" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4271" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4272" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-292-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span> − 1 and another will show x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4273" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4274" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-293-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>1 which is a future value. Therefore, clearly it is a case of Dynamic system.

**d) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4275" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4276" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4277" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4278" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4279" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4280" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4281" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4282" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4283" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4284" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4285" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4286" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4287" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4288" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-294-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = cos \[*x*(*t*)\]

In this case, as the system is cosine function it has a certain domain of values which lies between -1 to +1. Therefore, whatever values we will put we will get the result within specified limit. Therefore, it is a static system

From the above examples, we can draw the following conclusions −

-   All time shifting cases signals are dynamic signals.
-   In case of time scaling too, all signals are dynamic signals.
-   Integration cases signals are dynamic signals.

Digital Signal Processing - Causal Systems
==========================================

Previously, we saw that the system needs to be independent from the future and past values to become static. In this case, the condition is almost same with little modification. Here, for the system to be causal, it should be independent from the future values only. That means past dependency will cause no problem for the system from becoming causal.

Causal systems are practically or physically realizable system. Let us consider some examples to understand this much better.

Examples
--------

Let us consider the following signals.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4289" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4290" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4291" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4292" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4293" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4294" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4295" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4296" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4297" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4298" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-295-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*)

Here, the signal is only dependent on the present values of x. For example if we substitute t = 3, the result will show for that instant of time only. Therefore, as it has no dependence on future value, we can call it a Causal system.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4299" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4300" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4301" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4302" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4303" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4304" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4305" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4306" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4307" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4308" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4309" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4310" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-296-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* − 1)

Here, the system depends on past values. For instance if we substitute t = 3, the expression will reduce to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4311" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4312" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-297-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>2, which is a past value against our input. At no instance, it depends upon future values. Therefore, this system is also a causal system.

**c) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4313" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4314" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4315" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4316" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4317" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4318" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4319" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4320" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4321" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4322" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4323" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4324" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4325" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4326" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4327" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4328" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4329" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-298-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + *x*(*t* + 1)

In this case, the system has two parts. The part x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4330" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4331" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-299-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t*, as we have discussed earlier, depends only upon the present values. So, there is no issue with it. However, if we take the case of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4332" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4333" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4334" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4335" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-300-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* + 1, it clearly depends on the future values because if we put t = 1, the expression will reduce to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4336" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4337" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-301-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>2 which is future value. Therefore, it is not causal.

DSP - Non-Causal Systems
========================

A non-causal system is just opposite to that of causal system. If a system depends upon the future values of the input at any instant of the time then the system is said to be non-causal system.

Examples
--------

Let us take some examples and try to understand this in a better way.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4338" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4339" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4340" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4341" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4342" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4343" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4344" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4345" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4346" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4347" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4348" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4349" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-302-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* + 1)

We have already discussed this system in causal system too. For any input, it will reduce the system to its future value. For instance, if we put t = 2, it will reduce to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4350" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4351" class="MJXp-mn">3</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-303-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>3, which is a future value. Therefore, the system is Non-Causal.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4352" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4353" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4354" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4355" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4356" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4357" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4358" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4359" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4360" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4361" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4362" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4363" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4364" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4365" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4366" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4367" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4368" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-304-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + *x*(*t* + 2)

In this case, x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4369" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4370" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-305-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* is purely a present value dependent function. We have already discussed that x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4371" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4372" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4373" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4374" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-306-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* + 2 function is future dependent because for t = 3 it will give values for x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4375" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4376" class="MJXp-mn">5</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-307-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>5. Therefore, it is Non-causal.

**c) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4377" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4378" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4379" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4380" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4381" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4382" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4383" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4384" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4385" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4386" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4387" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4388" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4389" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4390" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4391" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4392" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4393" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-308-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* − 1) + *x*(*t*)

In this system, it depends upon the present and past values of the given input. Whatever values we substitute, it will never show any future dependency. Clearly, it is not a non-causal system; rather it is a Causal system.

DSP - Anti-Causal Systems
=========================

An anti-causal system is just a little bit modified version of a non-causal system. The system depends upon the future values of the input only. It has no dependency either on present or on the past values.

Examples
--------

Find out whether the following systems are anti-causal.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4394" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4395" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4396" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4397" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4398" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4399" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4400" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4401" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4402" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4403" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4404" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4405" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4406" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4407" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4408" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4409" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4410" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-309-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + *x*(*t* − 1)

The system has two sub-functions. One sub function x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4411" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4412" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4413" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4414" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-310-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* + 1 depends on the future value of the input but another sub-function x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4415" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4416" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-311-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* depends only on the present. As the system is dependent on the present value also in addition to future value, this system is not anti-causal.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4417" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4418" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4419" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4420" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4421" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4422" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4423" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4424" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4425" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4426" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4427" class="MJXp-mn">3</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4428" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-312-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* + 3)

If we analyze the above system, we can see that the system depends only on the future values of the system i.e. if we put t = 0, it will reduce to x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4429" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4430" class="MJXp-mn">3</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-313-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>3, which is a future value. This system is a perfect example of anti-causal system.

Digital Signal Processing - Linear Systems
==========================================

A linear system follows the laws of superposition. This law is necessary and sufficient condition to prove the linearity of the system. Apart from this, the system is a combination of two types of laws −

-   Law of additivity
-   Law of homogeneity

![Linear Systems](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/linear_systems.jpg)

Both, the law of homogeneity and the law of additivity are shown in the above figures. However, there are some other conditions to check whether the system is linear or not.

**The conditions are** −

-   The output should be zero for zero input.
-   There should not be any non-linear operator present in the system.

Examples of non-linear operators −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4431" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4432" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">a</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-314-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*a* Trigonometric operators- Sin, Cos, Tan, Cot, Sec, Cosec etc.

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4433" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4434" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">b</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-315-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*b* Exponential, logarithmic, modulus, square, Cube etc.

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4435" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4436" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">c</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-316-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*c* sa<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4437" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4438" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">i</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4439" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-4440" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4441" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-317-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*i*/*p* , Sinc <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4442" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4443" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">i</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4444" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-4445" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4446" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-318-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*i*/*p* , Sqn <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4447" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4448" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">i</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4449" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-4450" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4451" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-319-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*i*/*p* etc.

Either input x or output y should not have these non-linear operators.

Examples
--------

Let us find out whether the following systems are linear.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4452" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4453" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4454" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4455" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4456" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4457" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4458" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4459" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4460" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4461" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4462" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4463" class="MJXp-mn">3</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-320-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + 3

This system is not a linear system because it violates the first condition. If we put input as zero, making x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4464" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4465" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-321-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* = 0, then the output is not zero.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4466" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4467" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4468" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4469" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4470" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4471" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4472" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4473" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4474" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4475" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4476" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4477" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4478" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-322-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = sin *t**x*(*t*)

In this system, if we give input as zero, the output will become zero. Hence, the first condition is clearly satisfied. Again, there is no non-linear operator that has been applied on x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4479" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4480" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-323-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t*. Hence, second condition is also satisfied. Therefore, the system is a linear system.

**c) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4481" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4482" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4483" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4484" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4485" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4486" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4487" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4488" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4489" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4490" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4491" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4492" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4493" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4494" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-324-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = sin (*x*(*t*))

In the above system, first condition is satisfied because if we put x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4495" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4496" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-325-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* = 0, the output will also be sin<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4497" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4498" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-326-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>0 = 0. However, the second condition is not satisfied, as there is a non-linear operator which operates x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4499" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4500" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-327-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t*. Hence, the system is not linear.

DSP - Non-Linear Systems
========================

If we want to define this system, we can say that the systems, which are not linear are non-linear systems. Clearly, all the conditions, which are being violated in the linear systems, should be satisfied in this case.

Conditions
----------

-   The output should not be zero when input applied is zero.

-   Any non-linear operator can be applied on the either input or on the output to make the system non-linear.

### Examples

To find out whether the given systems are linear or non-linear.

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4501" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4502" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4503" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4504" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4505" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4506" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4507" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-4508" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4509" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4510" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4511" class="MJXp-mo">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4512" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4513" class="MJXp-mo">)</span></span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-328-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *e*<sup>*x*(*t*)</sup>

In the above system, the first condition is satisfied because if we make the input zero, the output is 1. In addition, exponential non-linear operator is applied to the input. Clearly, it is a case of Non-Linear system.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4514" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4515" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4516" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4517" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4518" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4519" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4520" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4521" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4522" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4523" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4524" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4525" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4526" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4527" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4528" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4529" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4530" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4531" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4532" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-329-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t* + 1) + *x*(*t* − 1)

The above type of system deals with both past and future values. However, if we will make its input zero, then none of its values exists. Therefore, we can say if the input is zero, then the time scaled and time shifted version of input will also be zero, which violates our first condition. Again, there is no non-linear operator present. Therefore, second condition is also violated. Clearly, this system is not a non-linear system; rather it is a linear system.

DSP - Time-Invariant Systems
============================

For a time-invariant system, the output and input should be delayed by some time unit. Any delay provided in the input must be reflected in the output for a time invariant system.

![Time Invariant](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_invariant.jpg)

--------

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4533" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4534" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4535" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4536" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4537" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4538" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4539" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4540" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4541" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4542" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4543" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-330-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*T*) = *x*(2*T*)

Hence, the system is not a time-invariant system.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4627" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4628" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4629" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4630" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4631" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4632" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4633" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4634" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4635" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4636" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4637" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4638" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4639" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4640" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-335-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*T*) = sin \[*x*(*T*)\]

If the signal is first passed through the system and then through the time delay process, the output be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4641" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4642" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4643" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4644" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4645" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4646" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4647" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4648" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4649" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-336-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>sin *x*(*T* − *t*). Similarly, if the system is passed through the time delay first then through the system then output will be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4650" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4651" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4652" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4653" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4654" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4655" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4656" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4657" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4658" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-337-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>sin *x*(*T* − *t*). We can see clearly that both the outputs are same. Hence, the system is time invariant.

DSP - Time-Variant Systems
==========================

For a time variant system, also, output and input should be delayed by some time constant but the delay at the input should not reflect at the output. All time scaling cases are examples of time variant system. Similarly, when coefficient in the system relationship is a function of time, then also, the system is time variant.

![Time Variant](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/time_variant.jpg)

Examples
--------

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4659" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4660" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4661" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4662" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4663" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4664" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4665" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4666" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4667" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4668" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4669" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4670" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-338-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*\[cos *T*\]

If the above signal is first passed through the system and then through the time delay, the output will be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4671" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4672" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4673" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4674" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4675" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4676" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4677" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4678" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4679" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-339-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*cos (*T* − *t*). If it is passed through the time delay first and then through the system, it will be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4680" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4681" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4682" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4683" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4684" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4685" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4686" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4687" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4688" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-340-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*(cos *T* − *t*). As the outputs are not same, the system is time variant.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4689" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4690" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4691" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4692" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4693" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4694" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4695" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4696" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4697" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4698" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4699" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4700" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4701" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4702" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-341-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*T*) = cos *T*.*x*(*T*)

If the above expression is first passed through the system and then through the time delay, then the output will be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4703" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4704" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4705" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4706" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4707" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4708" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4709" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4710" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4711" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4712" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4713" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4714" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4715" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4716" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-342-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>cos (*T* − *t*)*x*(*T* − *t*). However, if the expression is passed through the time delay first and then through the system, the output will be <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4717" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4718" class="MJXp-mi">cos</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4719" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4720" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4721" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4722" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4723" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4724" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4725" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4726" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4727" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-343-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>cos *T*.*x*(*T* − *t*). As the outputs are not same, clearly the system is time variant.

Digital Signal Processing - Stable Systems
==========================================

A stable system satisfies the BIBO <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4728" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4729" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">b</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4730" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4731" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4732" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4733" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">d</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4734" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4735" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">d</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4736" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">i</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4737" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4738" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4739" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4740" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4741" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">f</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4742" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4743" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">r</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4744" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">b</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4745" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4746" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4747" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4748" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">d</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4749" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4750" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">d</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4751" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4752" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4753" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4754" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">p</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4755" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4756" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-344-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*b**o**u**n**d**e**d**i**n**p**u**t**f**o**r**b**o**u**n**d**e**d**o**u**t**p**u**t* condition. Here, bounded means finite in amplitude. For a stable system, output should be bounded or finite, for finite or bounded input, at every instant of time.

Some examples of bounded inputs are functions of sine, cosine, DC, signum and unit step.

Examples
--------

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4757" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4758" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4759" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4760" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4761" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4762" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4763" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4764" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4765" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4766" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4767" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4768" class="MJXp-mn">10</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-345-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *x*(*t*) + 10

Here, for a definite bounded input, we can get definite bounded output i.e. if we put <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4769" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4770" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4771" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4772" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4773" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4774" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4775" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4776" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">,</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4777" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4778" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4779" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4780" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4781" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4782" class="MJXp-mn">12</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-346-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*(*t*) = 2, *y*(*t*) = 12 which is bounded in nature. Therefore, the system is stable.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4783" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4784" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4785" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4786" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4787" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4788" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4789" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4790" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4791" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4792" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4793" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4794" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4795" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4796" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-347-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = sin \[*x*(*t*)\]

In the given expression, we know that sine functions have a definite boundary of values, which lies between -1 to +1. So, whatever values we will substitute at x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4797" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4798" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-348-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t*, we will get the values within our boundary. Therefore, the system is stable.

Digital Signal Processing - Unstable Systems
============================================

Unstable systems do not satisfy the BIBO conditions. Therefore, for a bounded input, we cannot expect a bounded output in case of unstable systems.

Examples
--------

**a) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4799" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4800" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4801" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4802" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4803" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4804" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4805" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4806" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4807" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4808" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4809" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-349-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>***y*(*t*) = *t**x*(*t*)

Here, for a finite input, we cannot expect a finite output. For example, if we will put <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4810" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4811" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4812" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4813" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4814" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4815" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4816" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4817" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">⇒</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4818" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4819" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4820" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4821" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4822" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4823" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4824" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-350-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*(*t*) = 2 ⇒ *y*(*t*) = 2*t*. This is not a finite value because we do not know the value of t. So, it can be ranged from anywhere. Therefore, this system is not stable. It is an unstable system.

**b) <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4825" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4826" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4827" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4828" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4829" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4830" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4831" class="MJXp-mfrac" style="vertical-align: 0.25em;"><span class="MJXp-box MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-4832" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4833" class="MJXp-mo">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4834" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4835" class="MJXp-mo">)</span></span><span class="MJXp-box" style="margin-top: -0.9em;"><span class="MJXp-denom"><span class="MJXp-rule" style="height: 1em; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1px solid; margin: 0.1em 0px;"></span><span class="MJXp-box MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-4836" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4837" class="MJXp-mo"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4838" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-351-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>**$y(t) = \\frac{x(t)}{\\sin t}$

We have discussed earlier, that the sine function has a definite range from -1 to +1; but here, it is present in the denominator. So, in worst case scenario, if we put t = 0 and sine function becomes zero, then the whole system will tend to infinity. Therefore, this type of system is not at all stable. Obviously, this is an unstable system.

DSP - System Properties Solved Examples
=======================================

**Example 1** − Check whether <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4839" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4840" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4841" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4842" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4843" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4844" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4845" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4846" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">∗</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4847" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4848" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4849" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-352-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = *x* \* (*t*) is linear or non-linear.

**Solution** − The function represents the conjugate of input. It can be verified by either first law of homogeneity and law of additivity or by the two rules. However, verifying through rules is lot easier, so we will go by that.

If the input to the system is zero, the output also tends to zero. Therefore, our first condition is satisfied. There is no non-linear operator used either at the input nor the output. Therefore, the system is Linear.

**Example 2** − Check whether <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4850" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4851" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4852" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4853" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4854" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4855" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4856" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-4857" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em; vertical-align: -0.472em;"><span class="MJXp-right MJXp-scale5" style="font-size: 2.889em;
