text-align: left;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4874" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4875" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4876" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4877" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4878" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4879" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4880" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">,</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4881" class="MJXp-mtd" style="padding-left: 1em; padding-top: 0.2em; text-align: left;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4882" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4883" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">≤</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4884" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4885" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-353-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>$y(t)=\\begin{cases}x(t+1), & t &gt; 0\\\\x(t-1), & t\\leq 0\\end{cases}$ is linear or non linear

**Solution** − Clearly, we can see that when time becomes less than or equal to zero the input becomes zero. So, we can say that at zero input the output is also zero and our first condition is satisfied.

Again, there is no non-linear operator used at the input nor at the output. Therefore, the system is Linear.

**Example 3** − Check whether <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4886" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4887" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4888" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4889" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4890" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4891" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4892" class="MJXp-mi">sin</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4893" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4894" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4895" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4896" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4897" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4898" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4899" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-354-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*y*(*t*) = sin *t*.*x*(*t*) is stable or not.

**Solution** − Suppose, we have taken the value of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4900" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4901" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-355-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*t* as 3. Here, sine function has been multiplied with it and maximum and minimum value of sine function varies between -1 to +1.

Therefore, the maximum and minimum value of the whole function will also vary between -3 and +3. Thus, the system is stable because here we are getting a bounded input for a bounded output.

DSP - Z-Transform Introduction
==============================

Discrete Time Fourier Transform<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4902" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4903" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">D</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4904" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4905" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">F</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4906" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">T</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-356-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*D**T**F**T* exists for energy and power signals. Z-transform also exists for neither energy nor Power <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4907" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4908" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4909" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">E</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4910" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4911" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">P</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-357-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*N**E**N**P* type signal, up to a certain extent only. The replacement <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4912" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4913" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4914" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4915" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-4916" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4917" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4918" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">j</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4919" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">w</span></span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-358-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*z* = *e*<sup>*j**w*</sup> is used for Z-transform to DTFT conversion only for absolutely summable signal.

So, the Z-transform of the discrete time signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4920" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4921" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-359-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* in a power series can be written as −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4922" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-4923" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4924" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4925" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4926" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4927" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4928" class="MJXp-munderover"><span class="MJXp-over"><span class="MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-4934" class="MJXp-mi" style="margin-right: 0px; margin-left: 0px;">∞</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4929" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.167em;"><span class="MJXp-largeop">∑</span></span></span><span class="MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-4930" class="MJXp-mrow" style="margin-left: 0px;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4931" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4932" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4933" class="MJXp-mi">∞</span></span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-4935" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4936" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4937" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4938" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4939" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-4940" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4941" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4942" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4943" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-360-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

$$X(z) = \\sum\_{n-\\infty}^\\infty x(n)Z^{-n}$$

The above equation represents a two-sided Z-transform equation.

Generally, when a signal is Z-transformed, it can be represented as −

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4944" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-4945" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4946" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4947" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4948" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4949" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4950" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4951" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4952" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4953" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4954" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4955" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4956" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-361-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

*X*(*Z*) = *Z*\[*x*(*n*)\]

Or <span style="padding-left:35%"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4957" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4958" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4959" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4960" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4961" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4962" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">⟷</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4963" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4964" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4965" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-4966" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-362-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span></span>*x*(*n*) ↔ *X*(*Z*)

If it is a continuous time signal, then Z-transforms are not needed because Laplace transformations are used. However, Discrete time signals can be analyzed through Z-transforms only.

Region of Convergence
---------------------

Region of Convergence is the range of complex variable Z in the Z-plane. The Z- transformation of the signal is finite or convergent. So, ROC represents those set of values of Z, for which X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4967" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4968" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-363-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Z* has a finite value.

### Properties of ROC

-   ROC does not include any pole.
-   For right-sided signal, ROC will be outside the circle in Z-plane.
-   For left sided signal, ROC will be inside the circle in Z-plane.
-   For stability, ROC includes unit circle in Z-plane.
-   For Both sided signal, ROC is a ring in Z-plane.
-   For finite-duration signal, ROC is entire Z-plane.

The Z-transform is uniquely characterized by −

-   Expression of X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4969" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4970" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-364-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Z*
-   ROC of X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-4971" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-4972" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-365-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Z*

ROC is the entire Z-plane excluding Z = 0, ∞, -∞

DSP - Z-Transform Properties
============================

In this chapter, we will understand the basic properties of Z-transforms.

Linearity
---------

It states that when two or more individual discrete signals are multiplied by constants, their respective Z-transforms will also be multiplied by the same constants.

Mathematically,

Time Shifting
-------------

Time shifting property depicts how the change in the time domain in the discrete signal will affect the Z-domain, which can be written as;

Time Scaling
------------

Successive Differentiation
--------------------------

Successive Differentiation property shows that Z-transform will take place when we differentiate the discrete signal in time domain, with respect to time. This is shown as below.

**Proof** − We know that,

Final Value Theorem
-------------------

**Some other properties of Z-transform are listed below** −

Differentiation in Frequency
----------------------------

It gives the change in Z-domain of the signal, when its discrete signal is differentiated with respect to time.

Conjugation in Time
-------------------

This depicts the representation of conjugated discrete signal in Z-domain.

DSP - Z-Transform Existence
===========================

A system, which has system function, can only be stable if all the poles lie inside the unit circle. First, we check whether the system is causal or not. If the system is Causal, then we go for its BIBO stability determination; where BIBO stability refers to the bounded input for bounded output condition.

This can be written as;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8302" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8303" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8304" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8305" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8306" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8307" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8308" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8309" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8310" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8311" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8312" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8313" class="MJXp-mn" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8314" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;">n</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8315" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">u</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8316" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8317" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8318" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-544-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span> = *u*( − *n* − 1) + 2<sup>*n*</sup>*u*(*n*)

So, Z-transformation of the signal will not exist.

Z -Transform for Causal System
------------------------------

Causal system can be defined as <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8335" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8336" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">h</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8337" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8338" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8339" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8340" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8341" class="MJXp-mn">0</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8342" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">,</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8343" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8344" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">&lt;</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8345" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-547-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*h*(*n*) = 0, *n* &lt; 0. For causal system, ROC will be outside the circle in Z-plane.

For stability of causal system, poles of Transfer function should be inside the unit circle in Z-plane.

Z-transform for Anti-causal System
----------------------------------

Anti-causal system can be defined as <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8452" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8453" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">h</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8454" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8455" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8456" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8457" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8458" class="MJXp-mn">0</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8459" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">,</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8460" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8461" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">≥</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8462" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-552-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*h*(*n*) = 0, *n* ≥ 0 . For Anti causal system, poles of transfer function should lie outside unit circle in Z-plane. For anti-causal system, ROC will be inside the circle in Z-plane.

DSP - Z-Transform Inverse
=========================

If we want to analyze a system, which is already represented in frequency domain, as discrete time signal then we go for Inverse Z-transformation.

Mathematically, it can be represented as;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8463" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-8464" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8465" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8466" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8467" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8468" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8469" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8470" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8471" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8472" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8473" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8474" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8475" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8476" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8477" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-553-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

*x*(*n*) = *Z*<sup> − 1</sup>*X*(*Z*)

where x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8478" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8479" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-554-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* is the signal in time domain and X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8480" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8481" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-555-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Z* is the signal in frequency domain.

If we want to represent the above equation in integral format then we can write it as

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8482" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-8483" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8484" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8485" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8486" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8487" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8488" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8489" class="MJXp-mfrac" style="vertical-align: 0.25em;"><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-8490" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span><span class="MJXp-box" style="margin-top: -0.9em;"><span class="MJXp-denom"><span class="MJXp-rule" style="height: 1em; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1px solid; margin: 0.1em 0px;"></span><span class="MJXp-box"><span id="MJXp-Span-8491" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8492" class="MJXp-mi">Π</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8493" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">j</span></span></span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8494" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8495" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.111em;"><span class="MJXp-largeop">∮</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8496" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8497" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8498" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8499" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8500" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8501" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8502" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8503" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8504" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8505" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">d</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8506" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-556-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

$$x(n) = (\\frac{1}{2\\Pi j})\\oint X(Z)Z^{-1}dz$$

Here, the integral is over a closed path C. This path is within the ROC of the x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8507" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8508" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-557-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*z* and it does contain the origin.

Methods to Find Inverse Z-Transform
-----------------------------------

When the analysis is needed in discrete format, we convert the frequency domain signal back into discrete format through inverse Z-transformation. We follow the following four ways to determine the inverse Z-transformation.

-   Long Division Method
-   Partial Fraction expansion method
-   Residue or Contour integral method

Long Division Method
--------------------

In this method, the Z-transform of the signal x <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8509" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8510" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-558-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*z* can be represented as the ratio of polynomial as shown below;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8511" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-8512" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8513" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8514" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8515" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8516" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8517" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8518" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8519" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8520" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8521" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-8522" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.111em;">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8523" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">D</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8524" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8525" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8526" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-559-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

*x*(*z*) = *N*(*Z*)/*D*(*Z*)

Now, if we go on dividing the numerator by denominator, then we will get a series as shown below

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8527" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-8528" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8529" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8530" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8531" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8532" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8533" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8534" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8535" class="MJXp-mn">0</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8536" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8537" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8538" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8539" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8540" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8541" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8542" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8543" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8544" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8545" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8546" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8547" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8548" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8549" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8550" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8551" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8552" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8553" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8554" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8555" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8556" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8557" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8558" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8559" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8560" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8561" class="MJXp-mspace" style="width: 1em; height: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8562" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8563" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8564" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8565" class="MJXp-mspace" style="width: 1em; height: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8566" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8567" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8568" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-560-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

*X*(*z*) = *x*(0) + *x*(1)*Z*<sup> − 1</sup> + *x*(2)*Z*<sup> − 2</sup> + ... ... ...

The above sequence represents the series of inverse Z-transform of the given signal <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8569" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8570" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">f</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8571" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8572" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">r</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8573" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8574" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">≥</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8575" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-561-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*f**o**r**n* ≥ 0 and the above system is causal.

However for n&lt;0 the series can be written as;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8576" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-8577" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8578" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8579" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8580" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8581" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8582" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8583" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8584" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8585" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8586" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8587" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8588" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8589" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;">1</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8590" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8591" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8592" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8593" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8594" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8595" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8596" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8597" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8598" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;">2</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8599" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8600" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8601" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8602" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8603" class="MJXp-mn">3</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8604" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8605" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-8606" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">Z</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8607" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;">3</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8608" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8612" class="MJXp-mspace" style="width: 1em; height: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-8613" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8614" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8618" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-8619" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-562-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

*x*(*z*) = *x*( − 1)*Z*<sup>1</sup> + *x*( − 2)*Z*<sup>2</sup> + *x*( − 3)*Z*<sup>3</sup> + ... ... ...

Partial Fraction Expansion Method
---------------------------------

Here also the signal is expressed first in N <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8620" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8621" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-563-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*z*/D <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-8622" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-8623" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-564-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*z* form.

If it is a rational fraction it will be represented as follows;

Digital Signal Processing - DFT Introduction
============================================

Like continuous time signal Fourier transform, discrete time Fourier Transform can be used to represent a discrete sequence into its equivalent frequency domain representation and LTI discrete time system and develop various computational algorithms.

X <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9437" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9438" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">j</span><span id="MJXp-Span-9439" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-9440" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">ω</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-598-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*j**ω* in continuous F.T, is a continuous function of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9441" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9442" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-599-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*. However, DFT deals with representing x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9443" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9444" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-600-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* with samples of its spectrum X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9445" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9446" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-9447" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">ω</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-601-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*ω*. Hence, this mathematical tool carries much importance computationally in convenient representation. Both, periodic and non-periodic sequences can be processed through this tool. The periodic sequences need to be sampled by extending the period to infinity.

Frequency Domain Sampling
-------------------------

From the introduction, it is clear that we need to know how to proceed through frequency domain sampling i.e. sampling X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9448" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9449" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-9450" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">ω</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-602-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*ω*. Hence, the relationship between sampled Fourier transform and DFT is established in the following manner.

Properties of DFT
-----------------

### Linearity

It states that the DFT of a combination of signals is equal to the sum of DFT of individual signals. Let us take two signals x<sub>1</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9968" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9969" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-629-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* and x<sub>2</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9970" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9971" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-630-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*, whose DFT s are X<sub>1</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9972" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9973" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-9974" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">ω</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-631-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*ω* and X<sub>2</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-9975" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-9976" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-9977" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">ω</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-632-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*ω* respectively. ### Symmetry

The symmetry properties of DFT can be derived in a similar way as we derived DTFT symmetry properties. ### Duality Property

Let us consider a signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10102" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10103" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-642-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*, whose DFT is given as X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10104" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10105" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-643-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*K*. Let the finite duration sequence be X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10106" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10107" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-644-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*N*. Then according to duality theorem,

If, <span style="padding-left:9%"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10108" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10109" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10110" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10111" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10112" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10113" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">⟷</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10114" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10115" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10116" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10117" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-645-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span></span>*x*(*n*) ↔ *X*(*K*)

So, by using this theorem if we know DFT, we can easily find the finite duration sequence.

### Circular Frequency Shift

The multiplication of the sequence x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10176" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10177" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-652-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* with the complex exponential sequence <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10178" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10179" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-10180" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10181" class="MJXp-mrow MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: 0.5em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10182" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">j</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10183" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10184" class="MJXp-mi">Π</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10185" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10186" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10187" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-10188" class="MJXp-mo">/</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-10189" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span></span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-653-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*e*<sup>*j*2*Π**k**n*/*N*</sup> is equivalent to the circular shift of the DFT by L units in frequency. This is the dual to the circular time shifting property.

If, <span style="padding-left:9%"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10190" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10191" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10192" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10193" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10194" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10195" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">⟷</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10196" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10197" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10198" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10199" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-654-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span></span>*x*(*n*) ↔ *X*(*K*)

Then, <span style="padding-left:5%"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10200" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10201" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10202" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; DSP - DFT Time Frequency Transform
==================================

We know that when <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-10365" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-10366" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-10367" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; Methods of Circular Convolution
-------------------------------

Generally, there are two methods, which are adopted to perform circular convolution and they are −

-   Concentric circle method,
-   Matrix multiplication method.

### Concentric Circle Method

### Matrix Multiplication Method

Matrix method represents the two given sequence <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13343" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13344" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-13345" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13346" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: -0.4em;">1</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-13347" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13348" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13349" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-796-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*<sub>1</sub>(*n*) and <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13350" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13351" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-13352" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13353" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: -0.4em;">2</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-13354" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13355" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13356" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-797-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*<sub>2</sub>(*n*) in matrix form.

-   One of the given sequences is repeated via circular shift of one sample at a time to form a N X N matrix.

-   The other sequence is represented as column matrix.

-   The multiplication of two matrices give the result of circular convolution.

DSP - DFT Linear Filtering
==========================

DFT provides an alternative approach to time domain convolution. It can be used to perform linear filtering in frequency domain.

Thus,<span style="padding-left:10%"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13357" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13358" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13359" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13360" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13361" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13362" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13363" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13364" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13365" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13366" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13367" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13368" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">H</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13369" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13370" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13371" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13372" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">⟷</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13373" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13374" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13375" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13376" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-798-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span></span>*Y*(*ω*) = *X*(*ω*).*H*(*ω*) ↔ *y*(*n*).

The problem in this frequency domain approach is that <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13377" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13378" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13379" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13380" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13381" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-799-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Y*(*ω*), <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13382" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13383" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13384" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13385" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13386" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-800-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*X*(*ω*) and <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13387" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13388" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">H</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13389" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13390" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13391" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-801-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*H*(*ω*) are continuous function of ω, which is not fruitful for digital computation on computers. However, DFT provides sampled version of these waveforms to solve the purpose.

The advantage is that, having knowledge of faster DFT techniques likes of FFT, a computationally higher efficient algorithm can be developed for digital computer computation in comparison with time domain approach.

From the convolution analysis, it is clear that, the duration of y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13506" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13507" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-807-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* is L+M−1.

In frequency domain,

*Y*(*ω*) = *X*(*ω*).*H*(*ω*)

Now, <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13523" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13524" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13525" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13526" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13527" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-809-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Y*(*ω*) is a continuous function of ω and it is sampled at a set of discrete frequencies with number of distinct samples which must be equal to or exceeds <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13528" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13529" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">L</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13530" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13531" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">M</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13532" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13533" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-810-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*L* + *M* − 1.

With <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13551" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13552" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13553" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13554" class="MJXp-mfrac" style="vertical-align: 0.25em;"><span class="MJXp-box MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-13555" class="MJXp-mn">2</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13556" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">π</span></span><span class="MJXp-box" style="margin-top: -0.9em;"><span class="MJXp-denom"><span class="MJXp-rule" style="height: 1em; border-top: none; border-bottom: 1px solid; margin: 0.1em 0px;"></span><span class="MJXp-box MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-13557" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span></span></span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-13558" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-812-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>$\\omega = \\frac{2\\pi}{N}k$,

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13559" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13560" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">Y</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13561" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13562" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13563" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13564" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13565" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13566" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13567" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13568" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13569" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">.</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13570" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">H</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13571" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13572" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13573" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-813-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*Y*(*ω*) = *X*(*k*).*H*(*k*), where k=0,1,….,N-1

Where, X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13574" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13575" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-814-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* and H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13576" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13577" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-815-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* are N-point DFTs of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13578" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13579" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-816-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* and h<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13580" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13581" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-817-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* respectively. <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13582" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13583" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13584" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13590" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13591" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-818-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*(*n*)&*h*(*n*) are padded with zeros up to the length N. It will not distort the continuous spectra <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13592" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13593" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">X</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13594" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13595" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13596" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-819-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*X*(*ω*) and <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13597" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13598" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">H</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13599" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13600" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">ω</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13601" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">)</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-820-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*H*(*ω*). Since <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13602" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13603" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13604" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13609" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-821-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*N* ≥ *L* + *M* − 1, N-point DFT of output sequence y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13610" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13611" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-822-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* is sufficient to represent y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13612" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13613" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-823-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* in frequency domain and these facts infer that the multiplication of N-point DFTs of X<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13614" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13615" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-824-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* and H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13616" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13617" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-825-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*, followed by the computation of N-point IDFT must yield y<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13618" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13619" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-826-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*.

This implies, N-point circular convolution of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13620" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13621" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-827-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* and H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13622" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13623" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-828-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* with zero padding, equals to linear convolution of x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13624" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13625" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-829-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* and h<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13626" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13627" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-830-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*.

Thus, DFT can be used for linear filtering.

**Caution** − N should always be greater than or equal to <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13628" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13629" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">L</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13630" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13631" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">M</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13632" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13633" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-831-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*L* + *M* − 1. Otherwise, aliasing effect would corrupt the output sequence.

DSP - DFT Sectional Convolution
===============================

Suppose, the input sequence x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13634" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13635" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-832-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* of long duration is to be processed with a system having finite duration impulse response by convolving the two sequences. Since, the linear filtering performed via DFT involves operation on a fixed size data block, the input sequence is divided into different fixed size data block before processing.

The successive blocks are then processed one at a time and the results are combined to produce the net result.

As the convolution is performed by dividing the long input sequence into different fixed size sections, it is called sectioned convolution. A long input sequence is segmented to fixed size blocks, prior to FIR filter processing.

Two methods are used to evaluate the discrete convolution −

-   **Overlap-save method**

-   **Overlap-add method**

Overlap Save Method
-------------------

Overlap–save is the traditional name for an efficient way to evaluate the discrete convolution between a very long signal x<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13636" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13637" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-833-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* and a finite impulse response <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13638" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13639" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">F</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13640" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">I</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13641" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">R</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-834-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*F**I**R* filter h<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13642" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13643" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-835-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n*. Given below are the steps of Overlap save method −

Let the length of input data block = N = L+M-1. Therefore, DFT and IDFT length = N. Each data block carries M-1 data points of previous block followed by L new data points to form a data sequence of length N = L+M-1.

-   First, N-point DFT is computed for each data block.

-   By appending <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13644" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13645" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">L</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13646" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13647" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-836-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*L* − 1 zeros, the impulse response of FIR filter is increased in length and N point DFT is calculated and stored.

-   Multiplication of two N-point DFTs H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13648" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13649" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-837-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* and X<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13650" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13651" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-838-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* : Y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13652" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13653" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-839-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* = H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13654" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13655" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-840-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*.X<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13656" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13657" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-841-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*, where K=0,1,2,…N-1

-   Then, IDFT\[Y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13658" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13659" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13660" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-842-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>(*k*\] = y′<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13661" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13662" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">(</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13663" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-843-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>(*n* = \[y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13664" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13665" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-844-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>0, y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13666" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13667" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-845-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>1, y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13668" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13669" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-846-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>2,.......y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13670" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13671" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">M</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13672" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13673" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-847-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*M* − 1, y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13674" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13675" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">M</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-848-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*M*,.......y′<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13676" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13677" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13678" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13679" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-849-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*N* − 1\]

    <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13680" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13681" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">h</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13682" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13683" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">r</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13684" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">e</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13685" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.222em;">,</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13686" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13687" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13688" class="MJXp-mn">1</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13689" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13690" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">L</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13691" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">+</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13692" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">M</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13693" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.267em; margin-right: 0.267em;">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-13694" class="MJXp-mn">2</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-850-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*h**e**r**e*, *N* − 1 = *L* + *M* − 2

-   First M-1 points are corrupted due to aliasing and hence, they are discarded because the data record is of length N.

-   The last L points are exactly same as a result of convolution, so

    y′<sub>m</sub> <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13695" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13696" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-851-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* = y<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13697" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13698" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-852-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*n* where n = M, M+1,….N-1

-   To avoid aliasing, the last M-1 elements of each data record are saved and these points carry forward to the subsequent record and become 1<sup>st</sup> M-1 elements.

![Overlap Save Method](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/overlap_save_method.jpg)

-   Result of IDFT, where first M-1 Points are avoided, to nullify aliasing and remaining L points constitute desired result as that of a linear convolution.

Overlap Add Method
------------------

Given below are the steps to find out the discrete convolution using Overlap method −

Let the input data block size be L. Therefore, the size of DFT and IDFT: N = L+M-1

-   Each data block is appended with M-1 zeros to the last.

-   Compute N-point DFT.

![Overlap Add Method](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/overlap_add_method.jpg)

-   Two N-point DFTs are multiplied: Y<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13699" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13700" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-853-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k* = H<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13701" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13702" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-854-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*.X<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13703" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13704" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-855-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*, where k = 0,,1,2,….,N-1

-   IDFT \[Y<sub>m</sub><span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-13705" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-13706" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-856-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*k*\] produces blocks of length N which are not affected by aliasing as the size of DFT is N = L+M-1 and increased lengths of the sequences to N-points by appending M-1 zeros to each block.

-   Last M-1 points of each block must be overlapped and added to first M-1 points of the succeeding block.

The resulting DFT itself is real and even. These things make it clear that we could possibly device a discrete cosine transform, for any N point real sequence by taking the 2N point DFT of an “Even extension” of sequence.

DCT is, basically, used in image and speech processing. It is also used in compression of images and speech signals.

DSP - Fast Fourier Transform
============================

In earlier DFT methods, we have seen that the computational part is too long. We want to reduce that. This can be done through FFT or fast Fourier transform. So, we can say FFT is nothing but computation of discrete Fourier transform in an algorithmic format, where the computational part will be reduced.

The main advantage of having FFT is that through it, we can design the FIR filters. Mathematically, the FFT can be written as follows;

<span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14866" class="MJXp-math MJXp-display"><span id="MJXp-Span-14867" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14868" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14869" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">K</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14870" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14871" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.333em; margin-right: 0.333em;">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14872" class="MJXp-mstyle"><span id="MJXp-Span-14873" class="MJXp-munderover"><span class="MJXp-over"><span class="MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-14879" class="MJXp-mrow" style="margin-right: 0px; margin-left: 0px;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14880" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14881" class="MJXp-mo">−</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14882" class="MJXp-mn">1</span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-14874" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0.111em; margin-right: 0.167em;"><span class="MJXp-largeop">∑</span></span></span><span class="MJXp-script"><span id="MJXp-Span-14875" class="MJXp-mrow" style="margin-left: 0px;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14876" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14877" class="MJXp-mo">=</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14878" class="MJXp-mn">0</span></span></span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-14883" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14884" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\[</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14885" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14886" class="MJXp-mo" style="margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0em;">\]</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14887" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-14888" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">W</span><span class="MJXp-script-box" style="height: 1.86em; vertical-align: -0.64em;"><span class="MJXp-script"><span style="margin-bottom: -0.25em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14890" class="MJXp-mrow"><span id="MJXp-Span-14891" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">n</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14892" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">k</span></span></span></span><span class="MJXp-script"><span style="margin-top: -0.85em;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14889" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">N</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-907-Frame" class="MathJax" tabindex="0"></span>

$$x\[K\] = \\displaystyle\\sum\\limits\_{n = 0}^{N-1}x\[n\]W\_N^{nk}$$

Let us take an example to understand it better. We have considered eight points named from <span class="MathJax_Preview" style="color: inherit;"><span id="MJXp-Span-14893" class="MJXp-math"><span id="MJXp-Span-14894" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-14895" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14896" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: -0.4em;">0</span></span><span id="MJXp-Span-14897" class="MJXp-mspace" style="width: 1em; height: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-14898" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">t</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14899" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic">o</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14900" class="MJXp-mspace" style="width: 1em; height: 0em;"></span><span id="MJXp-Span-14901" class="MJXp-msubsup"><span id="MJXp-Span-14902" class="MJXp-mi MJXp-italic" style="margin-right: 0.05em;">x</span><span id="MJXp-Span-14903" class="MJXp-mn MJXp-script" style="vertical-align: -0.4em;">7</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Element-908-Frame" class="MathJax MathJax_Processing" tabindex="0"></span>*x*<sub>0</sub> *t**o* *x*<sub>7</sub>. We will choose the even terms in one group and the odd terms in the other. Diagrammatic view of the above said has been shown below −

![Fast Fourier Transform](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/fast_fourier_transform.jpg)

Here, points x<sub>0</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>4</sub> and x<sub>6</sub> have been grouped into one category and similarly, points x<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>, x<sub>5</sub> and x<sub>7</sub> has been put into another category. Now, we can further make them in a group of two and can proceed with the computation. Now, let us see how these breaking into further two is helping in computation.

Initially, we took an eight-point sequence, but later we broke that one into two parts G\[k\] and H\[k\]. G\[k\] stands for the even part whereas H\[k\] stands for the odd part. If we want to realize it through a diagram, then it can be shown as below −

![Eight Point H\[k\]G\[k\]1](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/eight_point_h_g1.jpg) ![Eight Point H\[k\]G\[k\]2](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/eight_point_h_g2.jpg)

DSP - In-Place Computation
==========================

This efficient use of memory is important for designing fast hardware to calculate the FFT. The term in-place computation is used to describe this memory usage.

Decimation in Time Sequence
---------------------------

In this structure, we represent all the points in binary format i.e. in 0 and 1. Then, we reverse those structures. The sequence we get after that is known as bit reversal sequence. This is also known as decimation in time sequence. In-place computation of an eight-point DFT is shown in a tabular format as shown below −

<table><thead><tr class="header"><th>POINTS</th><th>BINARY FORMAT</th><th>REVERSAL</th><th>EQUIVALENT POINTS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="odd"><td>0</td><td>000</td><td>000</td><td>0</td></tr><tr class="even"><td>1</td><td>001</td><td>100</td><td>4</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>2</td><td>010</td><td>010</td><td>2</td></tr><tr class="even"><td>3</td><td>011</td><td>110</td><td>6</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>4</td><td>100</td><td>001</td><td>1</td></tr><tr class="even"><td>5</td><td>101</td><td>101</td><td>5</td></tr><tr class="odd"><td>6</td><td>110</td><td>011</td><td>3</td></tr><tr class="even"><td>7</td><td>111</td><td>111</td><td>7</td></tr></tbody></table>

![Decimation in Time Sequence](./Digital%20Signal%20Processing%20-%20Quick%20Guide%20-%20Tutorialspoint_files/decimation_in_time_sequence.jpg)
